comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: Thank you. Yes the youngest on our records was Ellen Woodman, aged just 11.

comment.author: 53879693@N02
comment._content: Wow, that's sad. They shared the same prison with the adults ???

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: Yes, it's strange to think that a child should have to serve imprisionment with sometimes hardened criminals, but during this Victorian period, girl offenders who were Catholics were sent to the Dalbeth Roman Catholic Reformatory School in Glasgow, after serving their sentence in Newcastle Gaol.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: How awfull, a criminal at thirteen and in prison with hardened criminals!

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: It's a shame there wasn't more information about the girls as they didn't have any previous convictions and the crime wasn't reported in the newspapers at the time. It’s interesting to think, what happened to them after leaving the reformatory schools?

comment.author: 68517554@N07
comment._content:
"See Claude Gueux. clever boy, generous, no doubt. But fate puts him in a society so bad that he ended up stealing, society puts him in a prison so bad, that he ends up killing.

Who is really guilty? "

Claude Gueux, 1834 (Victor Hugo)

Apologies for the poor translation.

What happened to all those poor souls ? hope things are improving ! still a long way to go

comment.author: 19347260@N03
comment._content: Their parents were probably working themselves. Society has changed a lot, kids weren't as closely supervised as they tend to be now. If you look at American history, they had children as young as four, working in factories or fields.
